fields.the_text:
Case #1: 23C

As part of my research, I spent a few weeks at the company 23 Critters in February 2012. The goal was to find out more about their creative work process / model and self-identity to be able to understand the potential of creative agencies in today's society.

Intro

23 Critters was founded in 2010 and is based in Stockholm, Sweden. 23 Critters or 23C for short started out as a web development company and has gradually expanded their work to web services, business development and custom screen solutions.

23C has a website with a minimum amount of information that somewhat contrasts their good network of developers, influx of jobs, steady backers and prestigious clients. They have a Facebook page and a similar Twitter account where they post every now and then, but most of their work is not made public.

23C consists of six autodidactic developers and hackers with a general problem-solving nature; four persons are partners in the company and two persons are employees. They are all men. Going back to the 90s they have been friends before they took part in forming 23C. They all have a deep interest in their work, share a passion for technology and to an extent also have overlapping ethics, skills and interests. I have a shared history with some of them in the work around Piratbyrån dating back to 2004. There is one frontend developer, three backend developers and one designer. The frontend languages are typically Html5, Css3 and JavaScript, with the extension of jquery, mootools and Sass. One person is dedicated to Flash. The designer’s main tool is Illustrator. 23C state that they favor open source technologies such as the Python framework Django but they also have some good experience in Java and PHP. They say on their website that they are not picky regarding what programming languages to use but the office discussions reveal that they dislike PHP. The argument is that PHP is both a badly written language with a lot of security issues but more importantly it is a slippery slope for web development. Here they voice a general concern over the state of development.

The concern is mainly about the low quality of product that PHP produces and the low developer pride it leads to “- if you end up installing Wordpress blogs half the day”. It might be an easy solution but it doesn't produce skilled developers and also impoverishes the industry as pricing for such skills is lower. On top of that it makes the web poor and boring and in the end gives the business a bad reputation. The developers at 23C have a kind of developers pride in what they do and know they can do better. As they state on their homepage “23C is a team of designers, engineers and others who are concerned about making the virtual world look, feel and function better”. During the period that I stayed with them 23C had two major projects and several smaller. I spent most of my time with a senior developer working on one of their major projects: an online retail store for the Asian market. He was exclusively showing me his work and transferring his knowledge to me by close interaction and collaboration. As in a master workshop, knowledge and craftsmanship in programming, concrete tools and programming theory was handed down directly to the apprentice.

The work process of 23C can be very informal because of the small sized team. It is initiated with general analysis and discussions and then continued with an Illustrator design draft. The draft is handed to the frontend developers that make the first mock-up of the design. Meanwhile work on backend system design starts. After this, depending on the size of the job, missing pieces and changes are gradually worked into the project.

The integration of the various parts is done in an ad-hoc fashion and is possible because they form such a small team. The iterative design process is a critical component in how they are able to integrate their different skills in production. The office that they share with a design and architecture company is located on of the main streets in downtown Stockholm. It’s an open office landscape with a library, kitchen and discreet conference rooms. The team has their workspace at the back of the office around large tables that form a rectangular shape. Small personalized areas are formed around big monitors where everybody can plug in their laptops, place their personal gadgets, headphones, cell phones, magazines and tech-related books. During the day coffee cups cram the tables. At night and when people are in crunch time, take away is eaten in front of the monitors. With such small work teams as three persons 23C have an informal work methodology that uses direct communication. This is facilitated by the open office space where they can address each other directly on the development of projects and also help each other on any issues that might occur, all with a minimum of effort. Discussions are mainly held on project iteration but also on design principles and developer culture as well as more general topics, from gaming and gadgets to biotechnology and science fiction or just the latest chatter from Reddit. The discussions play a vital part in the general information dissemination, in project development and in the production of the identity of the group. The discussions are creating consensus of projects and strengthen their identity, produce self-awareness and confidence. This is an important process for them to be able to push the envelope and be in the forefront of what they do in their competitive environment.

During my time at 23C discussions on the projects were often lively between the designer and the developers. What was to be the next logical step in the current project was sometimes sold with a lot of effort. For instance the designer argued for more time before he was ready to move into the next phase of development. Disagreements were iterated over many times and body language and sometimes strategic frustration and silence was used. Watching the meetings through the glass windows of the conference room I could almost touch the compressed moment of the creation of 23C. I really enjoyed the critical discussions and how they voiced opinions to really pinpoint an argument for quality, how to best reach beyond the customary and what was the real value of a product.

While the informal process seems to work well, the midday working hours could be a bit fragmented in terms of the hours of concentrated coding. Accordingly, a lot of work is done from home or in the evening at the office.

Work-hours are full flex so they can work where it is best suited, from home or the office. Since no mandatory presences are required sometimes the office is empty. As a logical and vital extension of the office space and full flex the principle is that everyone should be reachable on IRC chat. Here issues can be discussed and solved and questions posted for fast answers.

Lunch hours are used for meetings and discussions often at restaurants nearby. The topics here are often extended ethical or philosophical discussions on the state of development, work principles and process and ideological or ethical anecdotic reflections on digital, political and social systems.

Commentary

Primarily originating from the informal discussions at the office and during lunch, a logical thread of thought crystallizes. It is well summarized in the quote from the website: the systems surrounding us can be made better ( “the virtual world look, feel and function better”.)

I assume that the discussions can be seen as a way of establishing the identity of the team in the competitive environment of the company as well as in a larger ethical and social context of openness. In the discussions there is clearly a positioning against what they pinpoint as negative player protocols, services, design and behavior.

If I interpret this case in a wider context these bad entities often seem to benefit from hierarchical, closed and centralized systems. This is contrasted with open technologies such as the internet that has the potential to break and remake these systems. An adaption to more open and non-traditional forms of development and protocols is something that demands highly skilled agents.

To further understand the position of 23C we can look at two competing models of production: centralized and decentralized. Internet with is p2p topologies has made the difference between these two systems evident as it forms a digital convergence where almost everything is gradually being digitalized and potentially connected. This has opened up for a big change in the way we produce, distribute and consume in society today. The changes present both opportunities and threats for businesses and forces them to form strategies to adapt.

One of the first to develop a model for how open software development works was Eric Raymond in his book The Cathedral and the Bazaar (1997). “Internet-enabled collaboration and free information sharing, not monopolistic control, is the key to innovation and product quality”. He describes the hierarchical cathedral-like systems of the past in contrast with distributed bazaar-like system with more freedom. I think it is right to see 23C in this light. The informal work process set in the open office landscape is a flexible and effective model that draws from the common experiences as software developers. When the developers state that they can do better, it is about creating better services for their clients, but in a broader perspective it is also about pursuing a more general investigation and exploration of these possibilities to benefit society as a whole. In aiming for the better there is a time-aspect. Short term goals that relate to the business and more speculative goals that relate to the potential of systems and what systems could be.

The discussions range from utopian dreams for a better future to concrete everyday solutions and trade-offs in the existing protocols, tools and the company. It is possible to have a different type of organization in systems of work, in politics and society, but when it comes to the everyday interaction and maintenance of systems, interfaces, games, tools and programing languages it is different. Sure these systems can be extended, subverted and hacked but they must also be maintained and work.

I will now give some examples of how this plays out in the discussions on openness and enclosure, central and decentralised, hierarchical and distributed system and between the actual and utopia. The first several examples are of the working conditions and the competitive environment and then there are a few examples of reflections on interfaces, protocols, tools and games.

Contradiction between the ethics of 23C and the fact that 23C is a business can arise. Trade-offs are made between ethics and possible income, jobs and clients. Sometimes they refuse to work with clients they dislike, for instance they declined to make a website for a company that was in conflict with a syndicalist union. Sometimes the stakes are too high for them to refuse projects. They might engage with a client even though they have a business model of enclosure, like when they engage with subcontractors of Hollywood.

This shows the contradiction between the activist morale that aims for openness and a better world and the everyday trade-off of running a business. One of them formulates the relation between activism and business and with a kind of rationalizing logic - I want to take from the rich and do something good with the money, also adding activists always have too little money. To see a company as a way of activism is a trade-off between power and freedom.

The CEO said that the advertising agencies in collaboration with big media are making Internet ugly and bad because they are trying to uphold old regimes of control. He thinks other forms of less hierarchical dialogue might form over time with the help of the open principles of Internet. Meanwhile we do things we enjoy and are awesome.

He brings up the difference between working cultures in different countries. The hierarchical system like in Japan and low wages in England make the condition for web development poor in comparison with Nordic countries and the United States.

Sometimes having better solution, knowing better and being skilled can be used to “own” others, especially when customers overstep their boundaries. On one occasion he used the fact that people from “Media” don't understand the core principle of the difference between domain name and hosting to an advantage. The client has not been paying the bills and is trying hard not to. "- Take down the site," he says. -”They do not understand how the internet architecture works and that makes them weak”.

A friend of 23C that worked as a system administrator at another company came to the office several times to complain and discuss the working condition on the company where he was employed. He was concerned about the impossibility of the top down model of information flow in the work process where people on the actual jobs would have been able to make things better if they were only let to do so by their superior. He describes a conflict between the technician and managerial part of the company upholding different models and upholding hierarchical and horizontal decision flow.

He said that the operational managers at are experts at being managers but have no clue how to solve real problems, still they are occupied with prestige. - As a technician, you are a problem solver, they are meeting coordinators. It easily becomes “us against them”. In the end he got so tired of the unresolved problems and when an opportunity opened he just resigned from his job and started to work for 23C.

23C is a company that works a lot with software interfaces. Usability and effectiveness is essential both when it comes to products they make and tools they use. Concern over poor interfaces and services and discussions about interfaces as creative systems was on the table in various forms.

In the design process, how to make their designs intuitive but not generic. How their working tools such as different programing languages and desktop programs for design facilitate the creative process. What constitutes a good programming language, comparing the experience from different game development platforms and what possibilities and potential they hold. Trying to strike a balance between skills and knowledge thresholds. Interfaces that are capable and where one’s skills can leverage the it in full. Contrast the simple and brilliant interface of IRC for communication with the frustrating interface of Facebook while seeing its success. Compare the simplest and yet powerful command line with a messy desktop application that does the same job. Skills in programing and command line control can overcome design interfaces as a graphical layer and barrier to the more direct command and control of the computer and the world. Where is the common ground between skills, powerful and complex systems and simple interfaces? To answer this it is essential to seek creative possibilities in today’s technology dependent world. What possible interactions are there between the actual and its interfaces? What performativity does the interface hold? Is it closed or open, configurable or hackable? In development where special languages or tools are used, there is a web of feedback in the form of debug reports, documentation and support models. There is also an extended community of other developers on forums and online tutorials. Open source is favored because of the unique environment of knowledges and feedback it produces.

This is code in a social context, but coding in itself also holds a speculative force, as a transformative process, new algorithms, typed instruction can open up a path to the imaginary, new and unknown. Here coding leads to speculation on algorithmically and fractal potential, to machine intelligence and emotions, singularity, mind body expansion, dna, drugs, into a maze of emotion, ethics, memory, time, code and text. Coding, protocols and tools are an imaginary space of what is possible to think and do, a genuine art form with full fledged potential.

One criticism of Spotify as a centralizing service was particularly interesting in this context. The problem with centralized services like Spotify is that they produce consumers. Spotify makes people forget or not learn how to pirate. Piracy here can be seen as a process of finding new possibilities. Spotify imposes a central, monopolists consumption logic and where the knowledge to share music in other ways is fading away. So the critique of Spotify is that it produces consumers instead of active community members, actively taking part in the investigative processes for new possibilities and new search skills. The basic knowledge of finding information beyond playlists and knowledge of how to get access to closed forums or how to configure proxy settings. An alternative must break the logic of centralized services and still remain a tool for communication between connected people (peered clients). This will require skilled people that can make a decentralized concept work.

This is one example of a contradiction in the consumer/central and client skills/decentralization logic. The question that still remains is how it will be possible to attract a larger group of people to take part in these endeavors. How to lower the threshold and still remain decentralized.

The name 23Critters refers to hacking and gaming. Games play an essential part of the common interest in the group. Many stories and anecdotes were told about games. Games are systems that you can learn from and hack. Some of them jointly played World of Warcraft and were part of the same guild. The CEO told a story about how he spent a year in WoW and how he became a guild leader. He testified that he learned organizational skills for instance when he was directing guild members to do mining and leatherwork to be able to do produce things needed to engage in raids successfully. How classes and races in WoW could be compared and seen as a template for human relationships. Coded worlds leading trails to imagination. Looking at 23C I was struck by how lively, dense and open the dialogue and reproduction of their identity was. It has been rewarding in relation to the core topics of my research: how creative identities are forming in network society and to find clues to distributed knowledge models. The case has verified the everyday struggles, joys and conflicts these networked processes involve. That skills play such key part in upholding a distributed system and in bridging interfaced possibilities is something I will continue to research in conjunction to discussion on creativity and art (ars and techne) and to social models (gesellschaft and gemeinschaft).

Issues

To see a company as a way of activism is a trade-off between power and liberty. If a company can be a model of activism could there also be a way to ensure certain ethical norms relating to for instance open protocols and the commons?

What will happen when 23C grows, how can they maintain their creativity, edge and informal work method and not fall into the trap of hierarchical management?

A weakness in such a small and edgy team of developers as in the case of 23C is that the specialization level is high and redundancy is low. This can leave the company vulnerable in case of sickness or other unforeseen situations. A special case of this surfaced but will not be discussed here. How can one level between edge and redundancy of skills in a small team?

How can we level skill, simple interfaces, low thresholds with complex techno-social systems? 23C is a male homosocial entity, can that lead to problems in terms of the experience they hold within the group? The informal work process set in the open office landscape is a flexible and effective model drawing from the experience of being a software developer. Drawing from software methods like lean and scrum, how can such methods inform the distributed networked knowledge model in the continued research?

Special Thanks to 23C, and Youkali and Cat for reading.

fields.excerpt: Hacknight Stockholm 2012, make all - a report Organization: Sparvnästet in collaboration with the National Museum of Science Dates: August 15 - 17 2012 Location: National Museum of Science Website: http://make-all.se/ Limitations: The project is limited to one night and two days and to the theme of open technologies, net politics and social change
fields.the_text:
Hacknight Stockholm 2012, make all - a report

Intro We at the hackerspace Sparvnästet decided to organize a hacknight, the first of its kind in Stockholm. A hacknight is an open, self-organized, independent and free creative technology event, conference and around the clock workshop all in one. The hacknight that we decided to name “make all” took its blueprint from hacknights organized annually by the hackerspace Forskningsavdelningen in Malmö.

Similar community events, such as conferences and conventions link groups and individuals from different backgrounds including arts, politics and technology to the extended hacker community and discourse. One example is the Chaos Communication Congress held each year in Germany. The Congress offers talks, workshops and community activities on a wide range of hacker topics and could be described as having an exploratory (critical-creative) attitude towards technology.

Events like these play an important part in the culture of hackers and developers, as they offer an opportunity to meet like-minded people and exchange experiences, perspectives and knowledge. They lay the foundation for the continuation and expansion of the hacking community and enable the flow of the latest ideas, hacks and skills. In the wider context the events contribute to the discussion and understanding of the impact of technological development in society.

Over two days and one nights in August 2012 we realized our around the clock hacknight “make all” at the National Museum of Science.

The broader aim of the project was to create a public event of learning and experimenting with open technologies. We also aimed to spark discussions around crucial issues of network society and net politics like privacy, identity and security. Another specific aim was to create a space where the existing extended network of Swedish hackerspaces could come together and manifest.

Net politics The first step was to apply for funding from the Swedish Internet Infrastructure Foundation. Even though the application was rejected in the end, it stated our initial intention.

- Large amounts of personal data are being transmitted, copied and stored in the global network without the everyday user being able to understand the consequences and process of it.

- We believe that this constitutes a knowledge gap and that it can be seen as preventing a democratic development in society. If people are to be able to understand how technology affects their lives they must have the chance to find out how the underlying systems work.

- We believe that it is democratically crucial to create conversations and develop understanding, visions and practice regarding the policies and laws of the net. A good and physically graspable way to inform and learn is to experiment together.

We want to explore net politics, where power imbalance between different actors and interests on the Internet are considered with the networked user in mind. The power differences between more resourceful players, such as governments or large corporations create trust issues and a divide in network society when compared with ordinary citizens as technology users.

A way to level these differences is to increase awareness and the general network literacy by information campaigns, self-organized learning and active exploration of networked systems. Thus “make all” was to be such an event to aid the leveling the playing field of the net. This is something that also can be seen as a continued goal of the work of Sparvnästet and the hacker community at large.

In the application we pointed out how connected technologies come with rules and laws imposed on the network users. These regulations are the company policies of for example Facebook and Google services, as well as laws and agreements like Sopa, Pipa and Acta that potentially enable a new level of monitoring capabilities and truncation of freedom of expression. These regulations affect both the user’s digital and physical identity and the data associated with them, while our digital lives are handed to the cloud. Without knowledge, better alternatives and power we are often bystanders in processes where our personal data is the core.

The following statement summarizes the discussion as we try to explain the purpose of “make all” to a local newspaper:

- Now that technologies are increasingly part of our lives it is more important than ever with free and open systems. It is about power. If you are dependent on the technology that you do not understand you put control over your life in the hands of others. Therefore it is necessary to consider how these systems really work in practice to be able to relate critically and in the end build better solutions.

Basically, the primary objective of the event has a net political agenda. But this is something that the player that we collaborated with does not regard as equally important.

National Museum of Science and Nils Olander After the application was rejected our group was still determined to carry out the project. The biggest hurdle was to find a suitable and sufficient location in Stockholm. We knew the curator Nils Olander at National Museum of Science from before, and after good initial email conversations about the possibility for the museum to host such an event we decided to meet. The meeting was held at the museum in March, where we decided to go through with the hacknight.

We crystallized the event further at consecutive meetings held at the museum. The basic deal was that we provide our network and organize the event and the museum provide the venue with tables and chairs, toilets and outdoor space for food and extended workshop environments, technical staff, presentation possibilities and internet access.

For us it was crucial to keep the event open and free of charge. Even if that went against the normal way the museum would handle such an event, this could be resolved by letting people into the event through a passageway not leading in to the main museum exhibition.

Nils Olander did all the heavy lifting at the museum. He was a key person as he was very committed to making the event happen, he resolved the internal politics and was active in helping out with bits and pieces of the actual event. He communicated back and forth with the museum offices on our behalf. The offices seem to be excited about the project but at the same time a little worried about their image and how it would look to have hackers organize an event at their premises.

The internal politics of the museum can be seen in light of their willingness to realize the event and handle the risk of being associated with the bad name given to hacking.

An interesting aspect was the difference in their press release and the information we gave on the website of the event. The press release of the museum emphasized experimenting and was formulated to make the event look cuter:

- An event for all curious people who are fascinated by disassembling, assembling, and figuring out how things work.

While we on the “make all” homepage indicate a strong relation between technical exploration and politics:

“Because the technology you don't understand owns you. The technology that is unexplored owns us. “

Behind the scenes in the corridors of the museum the word hack was discussed and it was questioned whether it would fit their image or not. But ultimately, the museum was able to let it pass into the press release, probably by emphasizing experimentation. One particular word was dropped from the press release, lock picking. While it did not make it into the press release, the lock picking station was totally open at the event itself and also one of the most popular ones. Something that points to the process of institutional policy and also a difference between what an institution is willing to say and what they are willing to let happen.

It should also be noted that we did not question this peculiarity. We felt pragmatic and the time was getting short for the press release to be sent. The internal discussion of the museum that was a bit fragmented by an institutional summer disconnection had slowed down the process. The approaching event made a resolution necessary and therefore disparities were solved with a smile. Differences in opinion could be resolved for the time being but would still remain problematic. The tension could be explained by the museums anxiety of being associated with hacking as an unpredictable force. This is kind of key because it obscures the real participatory potential of the net that seems to call all of us as potential hackers (net artists) and essentially what Sparvnästet is aiming at. I will return to these issues of institutional anxiety and participatory potential later because this difference appears to be a major theme of my research.

Estimating work and extended network. We considered the project to be very feasible both because we were determined to make it happen, but also because our extended network seemed to be interested in participating both as guests, volunteers, speakers and workshop facilitators. With the help of the active community involved we felt that the possibility to make this a high quality event was solid.

Two of us had to work full-time for two weeks divided over four months to make the project happen. Jenny was among those who shouldered this responsibility. To run the actual event we needed about eight people taken from core members of Sparvnästet and also volunteers in our extended networks for things like providing hardware and cooking.

We planned everything on Tuesdays at our weekly meetings at Hemliga Trädgården in Midsommarkransen, Stockholm and also on specific days by appointment. Central to the planning was the Sparvnäset IRC channel. Tasks could be divided and feedback from meetings with the museum could be handled in the channel. Persons in the group used their network to contact lecturers and workshop facilitators and we made a call for volunteers in our extended circle.

We invited people from other cities to give lectures or workshops. We paid their tickets out of our own pockets and also opened up the informal economy of lending apartments.

To further spread the event we published a website at make-all.se and blogged about the event at sparvnastet.org. We advertised the event via personal e-mail, various IRC channels and to tech-related groups such as GeekGirl. We also reached out to a larger audience through invitations and information at services like Facebook and Twitter. The museum made a press release and public announcements on the museum website.

Before the event one of us was interviewed on national radio, a small notice appeared in one of the national newspapers and there was also a longer interview in Stockholm fria tidning. Some presentations were streamed and also accessible after the event.

With lectures on anonymization and net politics, workshops in Arduino, lock picking and web development for activists, open tables for exploring techniques and sharing knowledge “make-all” was a way to manifest and open up the extended creative hacker culture in Sweden.

A practical Intensity - the actual event

I will now share some of my diary-notes from the actual event. People from Sparvnäset are named by their IRC nicknames.

The event is self-organized. Nobody except the staff of the museum is paid and people work and participate on a voluntary basis. It is part of the logic to keep the event open and free of charge. The fact that money is not involved helps create a non-hierarchical structure and seems to make it easy for people to join.

Thursday In this big assemblage of people and technology, movement is needed. I begin with taking the public transport to the museum with a lot of things that were prepared in the weeks before: the sponsored Arduinos, LED-throwies kit, Wallman kits, the hand painted “make all” flag, a Go-board, walkie talkies, a print frame for the “make all” logo and color for t-shirt printing, soldering stations, an old laptop to be used for streaming, and so on.

Halfway there I meet up with other Sparvnästet members, Map and Jenny and they help me carry everything. At the museum we meet up with Nils Olander and the museum technician, and the group begins to work setting it all up. Coordination is minimal and informal, no division of tasks is needed, and things just get done.

I feel the power of the networked agency, we interact in sync, almost as in a trance, filling in where other left of, almost dancing and in professional collaboration.

The space is an old white painted stable with pillars and chandeliers in the high ceilings. By arranging chairs and tables we divide the room into two parts: one part is dedicated to open projects and workshops and the other to presentations at the stage. It is a conscious division between the more formal and a more informal sphere to open the room for a range of activities. There is a flow that comes from the moment. Spirit, resources and ambition. We “make all” happen easily, because there is skill and determination.

The large batch of Club Mate, the hacker beverage that has a great symbolic significance, is lost somewhere between Germany and Stockholm. We hope that it will find its way in time tomorrow.

Friday Cat fetches me by car in the morning to go pick up Adis with the party tents. At the museum we unpack the sponsored Arduino kits with great joy. Continuing on where we left of yesterday, we set up the party tent in the yard and soldering stations, Map tests the streaming possibilities, Cat makes another trip by car to get the food for the event that Suss has prepared.

Back at the museum Byo hooks up every table with power and plugs. 4zm set up an old Amiga computer for some old school games. Map writes a small program to control the programmable light. I set up a projector to project some visuals. Suss starts preparations for food. The whole place boils with initiative. The lost Club Mate arrives. We get an email from someone who will give some Android phones for all to play with, Map sets up his time-lapse equipment and Adis a server to hand streaming. The crazy assemblage of the event comes together over a special kind of confidence and concentrated fun.

When the first guests arrive at six o’clock everything is kind of set. First up is Dee who just adds to the group. She unpacks an Eggbot, a Raspberry pie and a bunch of other fun stuff from a giant suitcase on one of the large tables in the middle of the room. She starts to assemble the Eggbot that can print on round things. People from the Malmö and Göteborg hackerspaces arrive, setting up their projects; some more shady. More people from Sparvnästet join. Hanging out is mixed with individual projects, Vojd makes software for an Arduino instrument, Jwalk and others fold paper space origami, a homemade Geiger meter clicks on the table, 4zm repairs the joystick port of the Amiga computer with help from others. With a sleeping bag I find one of the corners in the room, lazily watching the continued fun that continues into the night before I fall asleep.

Saturday Wake up, numb body, hard floor. There were around 20 people at the pre-hack last night; even if the turnout was not too large the people who showed up lived it up. Nils from the museum who also slept over is very happy about all the people that bring initiative.

The main day of the event starts slow and we become increasingly concerned about the turnout, the moment of truth. But people are really starting to pour in after lunch. 4zm presents “make all” and we open the official program. The first talk is by Snuggl on graphics processing units (GPUs), shaders and floating-point calculations and how the OpenGL API works. We then continue with a packed Arduino workshop held by Hedvig Kamp and a web publishing workshop for activists held by Plan. On the white pillars in the large room, there is a hacker quiz; any means to win is encouraged. Outside in the courtyard the party tent is busy with various kinds of activities during the event, screen printing t-shirts, kids learning soldering by making LED-throwies, an ad-hoc circuit bending workshop, other random projects and food.

Initiated people take part in various activities, but although few in numbers, some of the ordinary museum visitors is struggling to find a way to engage, one or two even turning at the entrance. As organizers, we fail a bit because the pedagogical explanation that we have is not enough to motivate the uncommitted and to close the gap. It’s hard to bridge the knowledge divide with information or instructions because of the limited attention span, anxiety and skill-level of the non-initiated visitor.

A slightly older and curious man asks what he can do and how the event works beyond talks. The workshops are open and relatively easy to engage in if you have some basic skills and interest. The open table area creates small groups that engage in their own or collaborative projects. It is clear that it is important to come prepared and motivated in order to engage in practical matter directly. “make all” provides a span of low and high threshold activities.

The way to learn here is to touch and explore things as they are in front of you. Getting there can be a struggle. In this way the children’s attitude can lead the way. Some children play with a robot bug on the floor, I can see that they commit totally, lost in activity and play. As a contrast, others get lost in the ideas of the ordinary museum visitor and look for specific directions and instructions of what to do. The situation is an allegory on how to learn by exploring, of institutional fail, imposing of lost guidance and how unprepared un-readiness separates the visitor from the event.

The talks continue into the afternoon with an introduction by Phyx about locks and how keys work. After this many people gather around the lock picking table to have a go at the locks. The lock picking really works as a great example of a low threshold activity, as all you have to do is just join in.

As evening approaches Martin Millnert gives a talk on how the backbone of internet works and Andreas Jonsson talks about the Tor project with a joint workshop of how to set up a Tor relay. Submarine and Monki make a practical workshop on how to make 3D objects cardboard models side by side with a workshop on how to hack public transport NFC (Near Field Communication) cards. The NFC workshop is a good example of a high threshold activity as special hardware, software, a laptop and special knowledge is needed. As with many hacking explorations, the exploration is done in a legal gray zone.

The lecture program ends late in the evening with a less technical presentation by Monki on the so-called Hot Line riots. In 1982, a bug in the phone system was used to create unauthorized hotlines. Spontaneous gatherings of young adults in the inner city of Stockholm lead to confrontations with the police. 30 years later the Hot Line riots can be put in perspective of the current technological context and networked disturbance like the so-called Instagram riots in Göteborg in 2012.

The people from the circuit bending workshop suddenly enter the stage and hold a noise concert. The high volume of this concert gradually leads to people vacating the premises and most of the inner circle hit the “make all” party at Solna HQ. Others are left to close for the night.

Sunday We pick up our stuff. Everybody at Sparvnästet seem very happy with how “make all” went down. It was a success and the event attracted around 250 participants, a very versatile and fun crowd. An evaluation with the museum is scheduled for later. At a brief meeting we decide to continue with a series of workshops on the art of exploitation and Arduino.

Commentary Bridge the gap An interesting way to think about “make all” is to look at it from the dichotomy of the private and the public and follow sometimes conflicting oscillations between the museum and Sparvnästet. How the semi-private community of Sparvnästet when it makes the event, expands into a public space. And how the public museum makes a reversed journey into the semi-private community of Sparvnästets extended network. In this process the manifest and the hidden come into play as strategies to smooth the transition between the practical hacker event and the public image of it. One example is how the process of decoding the hacker context makes certain things and activities available but still concealed at the actual event. With the process of decoding, semi-private discourses can be preserved in the public event. The practical event as a manifestation in space enables a big range of activities and possibilities where the informal and the formal coexist.

The activities are seen from different perspectives and are dependent on the level of skill and interest a person has. There are things that could never be part of the program but that are part of the event as a hidden informal possibility. One example is the chance to explore the gray zone of the NFC workshop. Although these hidden possibilities are necessary for the event to be successful and fun for the more initiated crowd, they do not fit the formal program. On the other side of the spectrum we as organizers need to help with the decoding, to bridge the gap and lower the threshold in order to reach a larger audience. At the same time we know that too much explanation or public light may cause some people not to show up. It is a fine balance.

In the evaluation after the event, Sparvnästet reflected on the difficulties in handling the various skill and interest levels of the crowd. There is a difference in how people engage the space: by guidance or spontaneously, from a distance or close, with a consumer / voyeur attitude or with participatory engagement. Initiated persons who know the codes of engagement were compared with the people from the general public where a certain amount of explanation was required.

As organizers one goal had been to see if we could increase the willingness to engage, but in this regard Sparvnästet expressed a shortcoming. We were not always able to bridge the knowledge divide. As there was a limited time window for pedagogical explanation, lost translation was inevitable in some cases. We concluded that information could have been better, but were still unsure if this would reduce the gap and motivate people to start exploring.

The relationship between pedagogical explanation and participation is one of the realizations of the overall objective defined in the application. We stated that the event would give people new skills and enable decisions on how to use the Internet in a more informed way. The event provided this to a large extent through talks combined with workshops for practical implementation.

Hacker agency The frustration of not being able to bridge the knowledge gap can be seen in light of yet another convergence, how the public usually interprets the hacker agency. Public media describes hacking as a illegal malicious activity. In fact hacker exploration is vital for democratization and participation processes in a technology dependent society, because it questions otherwise hidden agendas and processes. Without the perspective and knowledge of the hacker our society would be more closed.

Sparvnästet opens up a closed community but in the process has to try to convince the public of this point of view. We want to create an acceptance for hacker culture and identity but also maintain its radical nature.

One strategy to smoothen a potential conflict with the public is shown in how the museum handles and cutifies the press release (as described above). The museum rubs the edges of exploration off to make the event more acceptable in the public eye.

Different strategies from manifest messages to withdrawal tactics are used to try to make the meeting between the hackers and the public happen, oscillating between frustration and vision.

Also in regard to the private / public, hidden / manifest discussion Sparvnästet acknowledged the possibility to ignore public media. We didn't want to focus on a negative image, but to focus as much as possible on the more initiated process and interpretation of the hacker agency. This is a semi-private positioning where Sparvnästet does not feel the need to explain and where the withdrawal is seen as an opportunity to open up a more internal dialog. The pedagogical process of explanation in this case opens up for vulnerability and possible misunderstanding.

The ideological conflict around the word hacker did break through in a radio interview that we decided to participate in one day before the event. The interviewer really confirmed the general notion of the hacker with a question about the supposed malicious intent of hackers. Vojd from Sparvnästet answered that a hacker is someone who creates and starts important processes through exploration.

This is one example of how the discourse of creativity is established and how norms of creativity and the transgressive nature of creativity come into conflict.

Hacking and creativity The process of hacking can be seen as creating a path in a field of possibilities. Make a smooth space out of a striated space, to use the words of Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari from Mille Plateaus (1980). The hack, literally, bridges a space of possibilities that was not possible prior to the hack.

Creativity like this changes spatial possibilities. The rearrangement will sometimes contest the power within the space. To clean the space and divide it between safe zones of private and public property, an entrepreneurial smoothing can be put into motion, perfect from the point of view of the liberal innovator and the maker. But there is also a more transgressive creativity where conflicts, grey zones, on different levels enable the making of a smoother path for the hacker and net activist.

Hackers and makers With “make all” two different genealogies were established. The museum seems to use “make all” as a project where they can test their agenda to establish a science center with experimental workshops and produce maker fairs. Sparvnästet wants to manifest the hacker community and also has a political agenda relating to social change and network awareness. The genealogies actually add to two different conflicting narratives. On one hand, the hacker and net-activist aiming for social change, on the other the maker and entrepreneur questing for innovation.

In the maker agency, social change seems to be a supplement. In the agency of the hacker it seems to be an essential pathway. The maker agency is of a more moderate character because it can exist without any conflicts to existing powers. The hacker is an information freedom anarchist and opposes and goes into conflict with systems that restricts the user’s freedom.

It might be to overstate the difference but it is substantial how the maker and the hacker are used as agencies. In relation to the public, the maker seems to be more open and maybe nice however also with strategies to make things and processes private property. On the other hand the hacker seems to be more private but also surrounded by strategies to make information and things more public and open. Perhaps there are two different motions here, one inward and one outward between the public and the private.

This idea must be refined later but the maker could be seen as a vehicle of cleaning processes where the conflicts are put aside. This then produces an non-political agency that can easily be made part of a liberal public.

The conflict is solved temporarily by the concrete nature of the event with experimentation and exploration as the common denominator. Between the two narratives praxis establishes a middle ground as it is seen as key to bridging knowledge: by exploration, in the workshop, at the workstation, probing, tinker, making - hacking.

To explain these differences was important, but to strategically ignore them was key to making the event happen. Knowing the temporal nature of the event, it was possible to do so, however continued collaboration with the museum was to be more of a stretch. This is something I will return to later as Sparvnästet and the museum consider more collaboration.

Workload On the event floor and during the process of realizing event I felt trust and confidence in the group, who worked without any explicit hierarchy like a distributed network. The voluntary and self-organizing model seems to be very efficient, and the project was a large assembly of skills and a great accomplishment.

In retrospect Sparvnästet concluded that the work-pressure for the persons who took main responsibility was sometimes a bit too hard. In ad hoc organizations key figures have to step up and sometimes shoulder the responsibility in an un-proportional way. While it can be rewarding to lead, we agreed that strategies for sharing this responsibility could have been better.

When a small group of thoughtful and committed people decide to make something happen, anything is possible to accomplish. At the same time the members of the group are dependent on one another. It is possible to create intensity but in the process rest is also necessary. The low redundancy/high dependency level is a risk factor in such projects and models of organization as well as a stress factor for the most involved individuals.

Issues At the retrospect with the museum we all seem to agree that we want to make “make-all” an annual event. This however was a temporary success. It turns out that we are not able to combine the radical nature of the Sparvnästet principle with the maker path of the museum.

How can we interpret this and further iterate the relationship between the maker and the hacker? This can be compared to, for example, how free software was turned into “open source”. I also want to explore strategies of privatization and public exploitation, especially in regard to the artist agency. One example is baiting people with openness and common processes.

Although the ad-hoc organization model works, we concluded that the strategies for sharing responsibility should have been better. The division of tasks in voluntary work can be unclear. Is it possible to find a way to even out the burden and reward without putting control mechanism in place that stifle the easy way to join? This could add to the overall question of my research on how to create and scale distributed knowledge models. Do organizations that depend heavily on key persons need another kind of model or can this limitation be resolved by my further exploration?

To expand this question to a wider context of work and art: the voluntary nature of our engagement should be noted as being possible because we get our income from other sources. Voluntarism in creative industries can be a way to exploit mostly young people. How does voluntarism relate to the models I am exploring?

The event had a relatively differentiated crowd, but 100% of the talks were held by men and up to 60% of the workshops were facilitated by men. We put in special effort into finding female speakers, but it was difficult. How can we find more concrete ways to actively create more diversity?

In relation to the installations that are specified as the final outcome of my artist research, is there a contradiction in the participatory format of “make all”? My method is performative; meaning that I will engage in the practice rather than represent it. But in making installations, does that mean that I have to I step out of the circle of participation?

Keywords Information, hacking, Internet, workshops, education, knowledge dissemination, DIY, hackspace

To Share Hedvigs lecture notes. Images. The time-lapse. Streaming riot.
